Award.AwardTitle: CIF: Small: Realizing Millimeter Wave Communication Systems

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division of Computing and Communication Foundations

Award.AbstractNarration:
Cellular networks are challenged by the limited spectrum available at microwave frequencies. In the past several years, various technologies have been proposed to achieve ultra-high levels of spectral efficiency involving the use of multiple antennas, serving multiple users, and shrinking cell sizes. Many of these technologies have significant potential but do not provide the high data rates due to the limited spectrum available. An alternative is to use the millimeter wave (mmWave) band between 3-300 GHz to provide high bandwidth communication channels. Realizing mmWave cellular communication, however, requires addressing the fundamental difference between mmWave and microwave communication. mmWave networks will require high gain directional antennas at the transmitter and receiver to overcome path loss at higher frequencies and to ensure sufficient signal-to-noise-ratio at the receiver. These directional antennas must be implemented using a combination of analog and digital signal processing techniques, due to power hungry mixed signal hardware. The cellular systems must be designed to support highly directional transmission and reception from their inception, and must also deal with the increased impact of signal blockages.

This research project will establish the potential of millimeter wave cellular networks by incorporating the key features and constraints of mmWave communication. To understand the potential of such networks, this project will develop mathematical tools to analyze the performance of large-scale millimeter wave cellular networks, explicitly incorporating directional antennas and blockages. To enable robust communication, this project will create communication strategies that are simultaneously suitable for the harsh millimeter wave propagation environment and the limited capabilities of millimeter wave hardware. To leverage potential coexistence with lower frequency signals, this project will investigate the design and analysis of a hybrid-access system that exploits the coexistence of microwave and mmWave cellular systems. A main theme in the research thrusts is to incorporate key features of mmWave communication into the algorithms and analysis.

Broader impacts of the project's theory, algorithms, and architectures are expected in diverse areas. The mathematical tools developed in this research will impact the design and realization of cellular networks with directional communication. The signal processing algorithms based on array processing and stochastic geometry will pave the way for a new understanding of millimeter wave wireless communication. Industry impact will occur through the Wireless Networking and Communications Group (WNCG) industrial affiliates incorporating the results of the research into their wireless networking technologies. The project will foster the training of graduate students in course projects and will reach out to the community through public demonstrations.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Data rates achieved in cellular networks are limited by the amount of available spectrum. Research in the past several years has focused on making better use of the limited spectrum. While great advances have been made in improving spectrum efficiency, further advances will likely be incremental. Using millimeter wave spectrum offers the potential for higher data rates thanks to larger spectral channels available at these frequencies. Using the millimeter wave spectrum, though, requires dealing with different channel and hardware impairments. The path loss is larger due to smaller antennas, the scattering is less significant reducing the available diversity, and non-line-of-sight paths are weaker making blockage and coverage holes more pronounced. Further, the noise power is higher in millimeter wave systems due to the use of higher bandwidth channels.

This project focused on understanding and enabling millimeter wave cellular communication, including devise efficient methods for configuring the antenna arrays in a millimeter wave communication systems and on analyzing millimeter wave cellular systems. Key results are summarized as follows.

-       Low complexity analog / analog-digital beamforming algorithms for narrow and wideband systems. This included developing new signal processing algorithms and multi-resolution codebooks for configuring the precoders at the transmitter and the combiners at the receivers. Techniques were also developed that reduce the hardware complexity, power consumption and feedback overhead of massive MIMO systems.

-       Methods for channel estimation in millimeter wave systems with hybrid architectures. Different compressed sensing algorithms were developed for frequency-flat and frequency-selective systems, involving spatially compressive measurements. Problems were formulated and solved in the time domain and in the frequency domain, in a way that captures space-frequency correlation in the channel.

-       Mathematical tools from stochastic geometry to create a framework for analyzing the system-level performance of millimeter wave cellular networks, accounting for different beamforming techniques and including complex propagation environments. This involved developing new stochastic channel models and using them to analyze the performance of complicated systems. Key insights were obtained into the relationship between the density of blockages, density of base stations, and beamwidth of adaptive antennas employed.

Overall, the results in this project our results make it possible for millimeter wave systems to provide high throughput with large antenna arrays, and establish the millimeter wave is a promising solution for providing high data rates in cellular systems.

The algorithms, analyses, and insights developed in this project will impact the design of millimeter wave cellular communication systems. Developments in the project introduce new phenomena to be modeled using stochastic geometry and an important application of the compressive sensing tool.  

Results from the project were disseminated widely through publications in conferences, journals, and overview articles, with early access to such publications facilitated through preprint servers. Technology transfer was facilitated by incorporating material from the project into high visibility invited talks at conferences and companies, as well as in presentations to the Wireless Networking and Communications Group industrial affiliates, and internships by the graduate students working on the project.

The results from the project have already been recognized by the research community. One of the project’s journal papers received the 2016 IEEE Signal Processing Society Young Author Best Paper Award. In addition, the PI received the 2017 European Association for Signal Processing Technical Achievement Award.
